title: Nachiketa and Yama
summary: Nachiketa, a young boy, meets Yama, the god of death, and seeks the truth about life, death, and the soul.
moral: Seek truth with courage.

title: Satyakama Jabala
summary: A boy seeks spiritual knowledge despite not knowing his caste and is accepted by a guru for his honesty.
moral: Truthfulness is the highest virtue.

title: Uddalaka and Shvetaketu
summary: Uddalaka teaches his son Shvetaketu that all creation is one with Brahman, using everyday examples.
moral: All beings are manifestations of the one supreme reality.

title: The Salt in Water
summary: Uddalaka explains to Shvetaketu that the soul, like dissolved salt, is invisible but ever-present.
moral: The self is subtle yet omnipresent.

title: The Chariot Analogy
summary: The body is a chariot, the intellect the charioteer, and the soul the passenger – only self-control leads to liberation.
moral: Master the senses to realize the self.

title: Indra and Virochana
summary: God Indra and demon Virochana both seek the knowledge of the self, but only Indra realizes the true Atman.
moral: True seekers go beyond superficial truths.

title: Five Fires and the Path to Heaven
summary: Describes the path of the soul through various realms, likened to five fires of sacrifice.
moral: Life is a sacred journey through purification.

title: Yajnavalkya and Maitreyi
summary: Yajnavalkya teaches his wife Maitreyi that only the self is worth knowing, for it leads to immortality.
moral: True love is the recognition of the divine self in others.

title: Story of the Great Sleep
summary: Explains the four states of consciousness: waking, dreaming, deep sleep, and Turiya – the ultimate state.
moral: The highest self is beyond waking and dreaming.

title: The Madhu Vidya
summary: The knowledge of interconnectedness – how everything is like honey to everything else.
moral: All life is interconnected and divine.

title: The Space Within the Heart
summary: The infinite space within the heart is the abode of Brahman.
moral: The infinite is found within the self.

title: The River of Life
summary: Just as rivers merge into the sea and lose their names, all beings merge into Brahman.
moral: Individuality dissolves into oneness.

title: The Ash Tree Metaphor
summary: The universe is like an eternal Ashvattha tree with its roots above and branches below.
moral: The world is a reflection of a higher reality.

title: Pippalada and the Seekers
summary: Six seekers ask sage Pippalada deep questions about creation, life, and the soul.
moral: Sincere questions lead to transformative answers.

title: The Breath as the Lord
summary: The breath (prana) is shown to be superior to all senses and vital for life.
moral: Honor the life-force within you.

title: The Ten Vital Energies
summary: Describes the five sheaths of human existence, from food body to bliss body.
moral: Human life is layered with increasing subtlety.

title: The Joy of Brahman
summary: True bliss lies in Brahman, not in material pleasures.
moral: Lasting joy comes from spiritual realization.

title: The Sound of Om
summary: Explains how the syllable Om represents all states of consciousness.
moral: Om is the key to realizing the self.

title: The Golden Person in the Sun
summary: The self is described as a golden being residing within the sun and within the heart.
moral: The divine resides both within and beyond.

title: The Dialogue of Janaka and Yajnavalkya
summary: King Janaka tests sage Yajnavalkya with deep questions about Brahman and the Self.
moral: True kingship lies in spiritual knowledge.

title: The Churning of the Ocean
summary: Devas and Asuras churn the ocean to obtain amrita, the nectar of immortality, with Lord Vishnu guiding the process.
moral: Great results require patience, teamwork, and divine guidance.

title: Narasimha Avatar
summary: Vishnu incarnates as Narasimha to destroy the tyrant Hiranyakashipu and protect the devotee Prahlada.
moral: Divine protection always comes to the faithful.

title: Vamana and Bali
summary: Vishnu takes the form of a dwarf (Vamana) to subdue the pride of King Bali and restore cosmic balance.
moral: Ego must bow before humility and dharma.

title: The Birth of Ganesha
summary: Parvati creates Ganesha from turmeric paste; Shiva unknowingly beheads him and later revives him with an elephant’s head.
moral: Every action has a divine reason, even in chaos.

title: Shiva and Bhasmasura
summary: Bhasmasura receives a boon from Shiva to burn anyone he touches, but is tricked by Vishnu as Mohini.
moral: Wisdom protects when power goes unchecked.

title: The Birth of Kartikeya
summary: Kartikeya is born from Shiva’s energy to defeat the demon Tarakasura.
moral: Divine strength manifests when righteousness is threatened.

title: The Curse of Ahalya
summary: Ahalya is turned to stone due to Indra’s deceit and later liberated by Rama.
moral: Even those who fall can rise again through divine grace.

title: Daksha’s Yagna and Sati’s Sacrifice
summary: Sati immolates herself after Daksha insults Shiva; Shiva destroys the yagna in fury.
moral: Ego and pride can ruin even sacred acts.

title: Samudra Manthan and Lakshmi’s Birth
summary: During the churning of the ocean, goddess Lakshmi emerges and chooses Vishnu as her consort.
moral: From struggle emerges abundance.

title: The Story of Dhruva
summary: Dhruva meditates with unwavering focus and is blessed with a permanent place in the heavens.
moral: Determined devotion can move the divine.

title: The Burning of Tripura
summary: Shiva destroys three flying cities built by demons with a single arrow, restoring cosmic order.
moral: Evil, no matter how powerful, will be destroyed.

title: Parikshit and the Snake Curse
summary: King Parikshit is cursed to die by a snake bite and listens to the Bhagavatam in his final days.
moral: Knowledge and devotion prepare the soul for liberation.

title: Ganga’s Descent
summary: Bhagiratha brings Ganga to Earth to liberate his ancestors, and Shiva catches her in his locks.
moral: Selfless determination can bring divine blessings.

title: The Boar Incarnation
summary: Vishnu incarnates as a boar (Varaha) to rescue Earth from the demon Hiranyaksha.
moral: The divine takes any form to protect dharma.

title: Markandeya and Shiva
summary: Young Markandeya is destined to die at 16 but clings to the Shiva Linga and is saved.
moral: Devotion can overcome even death.

title: Birth of Hanuman
summary: Hanuman is born to Anjana and Vayu and blessed with immense strength and intelligence.
moral: Divine grace makes one unstoppable.

title: King Sagara and the Lost Horse
summary: Sagara’s sons dig the Earth to find a stolen horse, disturbing Sage Kapila and getting cursed.
moral: Disrespecting sages invites doom.

title: Rishi Durvasa and Ambarisha
summary: King Ambarisha observes a fast with devotion; Durvasa tries to curse him, but Vishnu protects the king.
moral: True devotion protects against even great wrath.

title: The Curse of Tulsi
summary: Vrinda, a devoted wife, curses Vishnu for deceit, and from her devotion, the Tulsi plant is born.
moral: Pure love and devotion transform into divine blessings.

title: Gajendra Moksha
summary: An elephant king prays to Vishnu while caught by a crocodile and is rescued, attaining liberation.
moral: Sincere prayer in distress reaches the divine.

title: The Elephant-Headed Ganesha
summary: After Parvati creates Ganesha to guard her privacy, Shiva unknowingly beheads him. Later, he revives him with an elephant's head.
moral: Even divine conflicts resolve with understanding and love.

title: Sudarshana Chakra and Sage Durvasa
summary: Durvasa insults Lord Vishnu’s devotee Ambarisha. Vishnu’s discus chases him until he surrenders.
moral: Divine protection shields true devotion.

title: The Killing of Kamsa
summary: Krishna slays the tyrant Kamsa, ending his reign of terror over Mathura.
moral: Truth and justice eventually triumph over evil.

title: Savitri and Satyavan
summary: Savitri wins back her husband’s life from Yama through wisdom and love.
moral: Devotion, courage, and wisdom can defy even death.

title: The Story of Jalandhara
summary: A demon born from Shiva’s fury becomes invincible. Parvati’s form tricks him, leading to his defeat.
moral: Ego and desire are defeated by higher awareness.

title: The Moon and the Curse of Daksha
summary: Daksha curses the moon for favoring one of his wives; Shiva helps revive the moon in phases.
moral: Partiality leads to downfall, but grace restores balance.

title: The Poison and Lord Shiva
summary: During ocean churning, a deadly poison emerges. Shiva drinks it to protect the world, turning his throat blue.
moral: True leadership is self-sacrifice for the greater good.

title: Rishi Bhrigu and the Test of the Trimurti
summary: Bhrigu tests Brahma, Shiva, and Vishnu to determine who is supreme. Vishnu passes with compassion.
moral: Compassion is the highest divine quality.

title: Kartikeya and the Mango
summary: Kartikeya and Ganesha race for a mango. Ganesha wins by circling his parents, showing wisdom over speed.
moral: Wisdom often wins over effort.

title: Narada and Vishnu’s Maya
summary: Narada, proud of his detachment, is shown an illusion by Vishnu that humbles him.
moral: Even the wise can fall for illusion.

title: King Rantideva’s Generosity
summary: A king gives away everything including his food and water to guests, animals, and strangers.
moral: True wealth is compassion and selflessness.

title: The Cow of Plenty - Kamadhenu
summary: Kamadhenu, the wish-fulfilling cow, emerges during the churning of the ocean.
moral: Divine abundance flows to those in harmony with dharma.

title: Ravana's Ten Heads
summary: Ravana earned ten heads and great powers through intense penance, which led to his ego and eventual fall.
moral: Power without humility leads to destruction.

title: Matsya Avatar Saves the Vedas
summary: Vishnu takes the form of a fish to retrieve the stolen Vedas and save Manu from the great flood.
moral: Divine knowledge is protected through divine will.

title: Kurma Avatar and Mount Mandara
summary: Vishnu becomes a tortoise to support Mount Mandara during the churning of the ocean.
moral: Steadiness supports all great undertakings.

title: The Disappearance of Sita into Earth
summary: Sita returns to her mother, the Earth, after facing unjust accusations.
moral: Dignity lies in silent strength and self-respect.

title: Lakshmi’s Tests of Devotion
summary: Lakshmi tests a poor devotee's humility before granting him wealth.
moral: True devotion lies in contentment and gratitude.

title: The Yaksha Prashna
summary: Yudhishthira answers riddles from a mysterious yaksha to save his brothers.
moral: Wisdom and righteousness triumph in adversity.

title: The Origin of Saraswati
summary: Goddess Saraswati emerges from Brahma’s thoughts as the personification of knowledge and speech.
moral: Knowledge is born from divine contemplation.

title: The Slaying of Shumbha and Nishumbha
summary: Goddess Durga defeats the demons Shumbha and Nishumbha, protecting the cosmic balance.
moral: Divine feminine power protects dharma.

title: Dasharatha’s Boon to Kaikeyi
summary: King Dasharatha, bound by an old promise, exiles Rama for 14 years at Kaikeyi’s request.
moral: A promise, even painful, must be honored.

title: Rama Accepts Exile
summary: Rama willingly accepts exile to uphold his father’s word and the dignity of dharma.
moral: True nobility lies in self-sacrifice for righteousness.

title: Bharata’s Refusal to Rule
summary: Bharata refuses to be king and instead rules Ayodhya as Rama’s regent, placing his sandals on the throne.
moral: True leadership comes from humility.

title: Sita’s Resolve to Accompany Rama
summary: Sita insists on accompanying Rama to the forest, valuing love and duty over luxury.
moral: Love stands firm in hardship.

title: Lakshmana’s Devotion
summary: Lakshmana leaves his comforts to serve Rama and Sita during their exile.
moral: Service to the righteous is the highest virtue.

title: Shabari’s Waiting
summary: An old tribal woman waits years to offer fruits to Rama with unwavering devotion.
moral: Simple, sincere devotion is most dear to God.

title: The Golden Deer
summary: Maricha takes the form of a golden deer to lure Rama away, leading to Sita’s abduction.
moral: Beware of beauty that hides deception.

title: Jatayu’s Sacrifice
summary: The vulture Jatayu fights Ravana to protect Sita, sacrificing his life in the process.
moral: True bravery is fighting for what’s right, even in weakness.

title: Hanuman Meets Sita
summary: Hanuman leaps to Lanka and comforts Sita with Rama’s message and hope.
moral: The messenger of hope can heal broken spirits.

title: Hanuman Burns Lanka
summary: When his tail is set on fire, Hanuman sets Lanka ablaze with courage and wit.
moral: Even fire becomes power in the hands of the devoted.

title: The Bridge to Lanka
summary: The vanaras build a bridge across the ocean with teamwork and faith in Rama.
moral: No obstacle is too great when united in purpose.

title: Vibhishana Joins Rama
summary: Ravana’s brother Vibhishana defects and joins Rama’s side, choosing dharma over blood ties.
moral: Righteousness is greater than loyalty to the wrong.

title: The Fall of Ravana
summary: Rama slays Ravana in battle after he refuses to return Sita and repent.
moral: Arrogance and lust lead to downfall.

title: Sita’s Agni Pariksha
summary: To prove her purity, Sita enters fire and emerges unharmed, showing her chastity.
moral: Truth shines through even the harshest trials.

title: Rama’s Return to Ayodhya
summary: After 14 years of exile, Rama returns to Ayodhya and is crowned king.
moral: Patience and virtue are always rewarded.

title: The Story of Hanuman’s Ring
summary: To show Sita the eternal truth, Hanuman enters the underworld to retrieve Rama’s ring.
moral: The divine play is infinite and mysterious.

title: Sabari and the Sweet Fruits
summary: Sabari tastes each fruit before offering it to Rama, wanting to give only the sweetest.
moral: True love thinks only of the beloved’s joy.

title: Sampati’s Vision
summary: Jatayu’s elder brother, Sampati, helps the vanaras by locating Sita in Lanka.
moral: Even broken wings can help others fly.

title: Hanuman Lifts the Mountain
summary: Unable to find the Sanjeevani herb, Hanuman lifts the entire mountain to save Lakshmana.
moral: Determination makes miracles happen.

title: Sita’s Return to Earth
summary: After facing public suspicion again, Sita asks the Earth to take her back, ending her earthly life.
moral: Dignity sometimes means walking away silently.

title: Manthara's Manipulation
summary: Kaikeyi’s maid Manthara poisons her mind with jealousy, triggering Rama’s exile.
moral: Small minds can spark great downfalls.

title: Guha the Boatman
summary: Guha, a tribal chief, offers heartfelt hospitality to Rama and ferries him across the Ganga.
moral: True devotion transcends caste and class.

title: Valmiki and Sita’s Shelter
summary: Sita finds refuge in Sage Valmiki’s ashram, where she raises her twin sons alone.
moral: In solitude, strength and grace emerge.

title: Birth of Lava and Kusha
summary: Sita gives birth to Rama’s sons, Lava and Kusha, who grow up in Valmiki’s ashram.
moral: Righteousness lives on through the next generation.

title: Rama Meets Lava and Kusha
summary: Lava and Kusha unknowingly challenge Rama’s army while reciting his story, leading to an emotional reunion.
moral: Truth eventually brings family back together.

title: Hanuman and the Pearls
summary: Hanuman is seen tearing apart a pearl necklace, claiming only what has Rama’s name inside matters.
moral: Only divine remembrance gives true worth.

title: Sugriva’s Doubt
summary: Sugriva delays helping Rama until reminded of his promise, angering Lakshmana.
moral: Promises must be fulfilled with sincerity.

title: Sampati’s Sacrifice
summary: Once jealous of Jatayu, Sampati ultimately helps Rama’s army by revealing Sita’s location.
moral: Redemption is always possible through service.

title: Angada at Ravana’s Court
summary: Angada delivers Rama’s final warning to Ravana, showing immense courage by planting his foot firmly.
moral: Fearless truth challenges tyranny.

title: Kumbhakarna’s Awakening
summary: Kumbhakarna awakens from deep slumber to fight Rama, knowing his brother is wrong.
moral: Blind loyalty leads to downfall.

title: Indrajit’s Illusions
summary: Ravana’s son Indrajit uses sorcery in battle, injuring Lakshmana before being defeated.
moral: Illusion can’t withstand righteousness.

title: Vibhishana's Counsel Ignored
summary: Ravana rejects his brother Vibhishana’s advice to return Sita and embrace peace.
moral: Ignoring wise counsel invites ruin.

title: Mandodari’s Grief
summary: After Ravana’s fall, his wife Mandodari mourns his downfall, reminding all of wasted potential.
moral: Pride destroys both the sinner and the innocent.

title: Hanuman’s Tail Fire
summary: Ravana orders Hanuman’s tail to be burned, but Hanuman uses the fire to torch Lanka.
moral: Insulting a devotee invites divine wrath.

title: Sita Refuses Ravana’s Offer
summary: Despite temptations and threats, Sita never yields to Ravana’s advances.
moral: Purity and willpower withstand all evil.

title: The Squirrel’s Help
summary: A tiny squirrel contributes to the bridge-building effort, earning Rama’s affection.
moral: No effort is too small in service of dharma.

title: Hanuman and the Sun
summary: As a child, Hanuman tries to eat the sun, mistaking it for a fruit.
moral: Divine beings show greatness from birth.

title: Vishwamitra’s Request
summary: Sage Vishwamitra requests Rama to protect his yagna from demons, initiating Rama’s heroic journey.
moral: Great journeys begin with small acts of service.

title: Ahalya’s Redemption
summary: Ahalya, cursed to be stone, is redeemed by Rama’s touch and restored to grace.
moral: Divine grace redeems even the fallen.

title: Sita's Shadow
summary: Before abduction, Agni hides the real Sita and replaces her with a shadow to protect her purity.
moral: The divine protects what must remain untouched.

title: Birth of the Pandavas
summary: Kunti invokes divine beings using a boon and gives birth to Yudhishthira, Bhima, and Arjuna. Madri bears Nakula and Sahadeva.
moral: Divine gifts come with great responsibility.

title: Drona's Test of Loyalty
summary: Drona demands Ekalavya’s thumb as guru dakshina to ensure Arjuna remains unrivaled.
moral: Favoritism can destroy innocent brilliance.

title: Bhishma’s Vow
summary: Bhishma vows lifelong celibacy so his father can marry Satyavati.
moral: Selflessness can shape destinies.

title: Karna’s Birth and Abandonment
summary: Born to Kunti before her marriage, Karna is abandoned and raised by a charioteer.
moral: Greatness can rise from humble beginnings.

title: The Game of Dice
summary: Yudhishthira loses everything, including his brothers and wife, in a rigged dice game.
moral: Addiction to pride and ego leads to ruin.

title: Draupadi’s Vastraharan
summary: Dushasana attempts to disrobe Draupadi in the court, but Krishna protects her dignity.
moral: Divine intervention protects the righteous.

title: Krishna Breaks His Vow
summary: In the war, Krishna almost attacks Bhishma with a wheel, showing that love transcends promises.
moral: Compassion can override even divine vows.

title: Arjuna’s Refusal to Fight
summary: Seeing his relatives on both sides, Arjuna hesitates to fight until Krishna gives him divine counsel.
moral: Dharma must be upheld even in pain.

title: Abhimanyu and the Chakravyuha
summary: Abhimanyu enters the deadly war formation but is trapped and killed due to incomplete knowledge.
moral: Half knowledge can be fatal.

title: Karna’s Generosity
summary: Despite knowing his end is near, Karna gives away his armor and earrings to Indra.
moral: True greatness lies in giving, not getting.

title: Kunti’s Revelation to Karna
summary: Before the war, Kunti reveals to Karna that he is her son, but he refuses to betray Duryodhana.
moral: Loyalty can sometimes outweigh blood.

title: Duryodhana’s Jealousy
summary: Unable to accept the Pandavas’ success, Duryodhana plots to burn them alive in the Lakshagriha.
moral: Envy blinds and corrupts the soul.

title: Shakuni’s Manipulation
summary: Shakuni masterminds the game of dice and manipulates Duryodhana for revenge.
moral: Cunning may win battles, but not the war.

title: Krishna as Peace Messenger
summary: Krishna tries to negotiate peace before the war, but Duryodhana rejects all efforts.
moral: Ego ruins the chance for peace.

title: Bhima and Duryodhana’s Final Duel
summary: Bhima breaks Duryodhana’s thighs in a mace duel, avenging Draupadi’s humiliation.
moral: Justice delayed is still justice served.

title: Ghatotkacha’s Sacrifice
summary: Ghatotkacha uses his demonic powers in war and forces Karna to use his divine weapon early.
moral: Sacrifice of one can save many.

title: Ashwatthama’s Revenge
summary: After the war, Ashwatthama kills the sleeping sons of the Pandavas, committing a grave sin.
moral: Revenge born in grief only deepens suffering.

title: The Story of Uttara and Arjuna
summary: During exile, Arjuna teaches Prince Uttara to fight, disguised as a eunuch named Brihannala.
moral: Wisdom can wear many forms.

title: Vidura’s Wisdom
summary: Vidura, the wise minister, constantly advises Dhritarashtra to choose dharma over favoritism.
moral: Neutral wisdom is the hardest to follow.

title: Draupadi’s Swayamvara
summary: Arjuna wins Draupadi’s hand by piercing a rotating fish’s eye using a bow.
moral: Focus and skill win over strength.

title: Yudhishthira’s Honesty
summary: Yudhishthira always chooses truth and righteousness, even in pain and loss.
moral: Dharma is more important than victory.

title: Bhima Kills Bakasura
summary: Bhima defeats the demon Bakasura who terrorized villagers by demanding human sacrifice.
moral: Strength must protect the weak.

title: Arjuna Gets the Gandiva
summary: Arjuna receives the divine bow Gandiva and celestial weapons during his penance to Lord Shiva.
moral: Divine power comes through discipline.

title: Duryodhana in the Palace of Illusions
summary: Duryodhana falls in a pool mistaking it for a floor in Yudhishthira’s palace and is mocked by Draupadi.
moral: Pride often ends in humiliation.

title: Arjuna’s Penance and Shiva’s Boon
summary: Arjuna performs intense penance and wins Shiva’s favor by unknowingly dueling him.
moral: True devotion is tested through humility and patience.

title: The House of Lac (Lakshagriha)
summary: Duryodhana builds a palace of wax to burn the Pandavas, but they escape through a secret tunnel.
moral: Evil schemes crumble before clever planning.

title: Kichaka's Death
summary: Bhima kills Kichaka who tries to harass Draupadi during their exile in disguise.
moral: The strong must rise to defend honor.

title: The Yaksha Prashna
summary: Yudhishthira answers a Yaksha’s riddles wisely to revive his brothers.
moral: Wisdom and patience can overcome the direst trials.

title: Krishna’s Vishvarupa
summary: During the Gita discourse, Krishna reveals his cosmic form to Arjuna.
moral: Divinity transcends the visible and personal.

title: Satyavati’s Secret
summary: Satyavati, mother of Vyasa, reveals her past and invokes him to preserve the Kuru lineage.
moral: Secrets may shape destiny in unexpected ways.

title: Gambling Away Draupadi
summary: Yudhishthira stakes Draupadi after losing himself in the game of dice.
moral: Lack of restraint in desire causes moral collapse.

title: Drona’s Death
summary: Yudhishthira falsely says Ashwatthama is dead, leading to Drona’s defeat.
moral: Even noble intentions may demand painful choices.

title: Jayadratha’s Death
summary: Arjuna slays Jayadratha before sunset with Krishna’s strategic illusion.
moral: Timely strategy wins battles where strength alone fails.

title: Karna vs Arjuna
summary: Karna dies in battle after his chariot wheel gets stuck, and he is weaponless.
moral: Fate strikes even the mighty when dharma is ignored.

title: The Curse of Gandhari
summary: Gandhari curses Krishna that his clan will perish, grieving her sons’ deaths.
moral: Even divine plans have consequences.

title: Krishna’s Death
summary: A hunter mistakenly kills Krishna, fulfilling Gandhari’s curse and ending the Yadava dynasty.
moral: Every avatar fulfills a cycle before departing.

title: Dhritarashtra’s Blindness
summary: Born blind, Dhritarashtra represents physical and moral blindness in his reign.
moral: Ignoring wrong is worse than committing it.

title: Arjuna’s Pride Humbled
summary: Hanuman appears on Arjuna’s flag and humbles his pride in a duel of bridges.
moral: Pride dissolves before true devotion.

title: Bhishma on the Bed of Arrows
summary: After being defeated, Bhishma lies on a bed of arrows until he chooses the moment of his death.
moral: Even warriors die with wisdom and grace.

title: Shikhandi and Bhishma
summary: Bhishma lowers his weapons before Shikhandi, enabling Arjuna to defeat him.
moral: Past actions return in unexpected forms.

title: Amba’s Vengeance
summary: Rejected by Bhishma, Amba is reborn as Shikhandi to take revenge.
moral: Deep hurt seeks closure across lifetimes.

title: Kripa and Ashwatthama Survive
summary: After the war, the cursed Ashwatthama and Kripacharya survive as immortals.
moral: Immortality without peace is punishment.

title: The Fall of the Kauravas
summary: All of Dhritarashtra’s sons, including Duryodhana and Dusshasana, fall in the war.
moral: Unrighteous ambition ends in ruin.

title: Draupadi’s Five Husbands
summary: Draupadi is married to all five Pandavas due to a divine boon from a previous birth.
moral: Destiny unfolds in ways we may not understand.

title: Sanjaya’s Vision
summary: Sage Vyasa grants Sanjaya divine sight to narrate the war to blind king Dhritarashtra.
moral: Truth sees beyond what eyes can perceive.

title: Pandavas' Journey to Heaven
summary: One by one, the Pandavas fall during their final pilgrimage, revealing their human flaws.
moral: No one escapes the judgment of dharma.

title: Yudhishthira’s Final Test
summary: Yudhishthira is tested by the gods with illusions in heaven, choosing dharma even there.
moral: True dharma holds firm beyond life.

title: Dog at Heaven’s Gate
summary: A loyal dog follows Yudhishthira to heaven. He refuses to enter without the dog, which is revealed to be Dharma himself.
moral: Loyalty and compassion are higher than heaven.

title: Bhima’s Rage
summary: Bhima vows to break Duryodhana’s thighs after Draupadi is insulted and fulfills it in the final battle.
moral: Vows born of pain carry immense power.

title: The Monkey and the Crocodile
summary: A clever monkey escapes the crocodile’s trap using his wit.
moral: Wisdom can save you from danger.

title: The Tortoise and the Geese
summary: A tortoise can't resist speaking mid-flight and falls to his death.
moral: Think before you speak.

title: The Lion and the Mouse
summary: A lion spares a mouse, which later frees him from a hunter’s net.
moral: No act of kindness is ever wasted.

title: The Crane and the Crab
summary: A deceitful crane eats the fish it promised to save, but the crab avenges them.
moral: Harm others and pay the price.

title: The Blue Jackal
summary: A jackal dyed blue becomes king, until it rains and reveals his true self.
moral: False appearances won’t last.

title: The Foolish Lion and the Clever Rabbit
summary: A clever rabbit tricks a lion into a well to protect the herd.
moral: Brains beat brawn.

title: The Monkey and the Weaver Birds
summary: A monkey ruins a weaver bird’s nest on the way to test his cleverness.
moral: Don’t boast about deeds you haven’t done.

title: The Brahmin and the Crooks
summary: A naive brahmin is tricked by robbers and loses all his possessions.
moral: Beware of flattery and false friends.

title: The Mouse and the Lion
summary: A mouse frees a lion from a hunter’s net, repaying his earlier mercy.
moral: Small friends can be great allies.

title: The Fisherman and the Little Fish
summary: A fisherman lets a small fish go, expecting a bigger one soon—but regrets it later.
moral: A bird in hand is worth two in the bush.

title: The Monkey and the Crocodile’s Heart
summary: A crocodile tries to trick a monkey to eat its heart, but the monkey outsmarts him.
moral: Thinking fast can save your life.

title: The Lion, the Hare, and the Ox
summary: A clever hare tricks a lion into drowning, saving his ox friend.
moral: Intelligence can overcome brute strength.

title: The Farmer and the Well
summary: A farmer falls into a well and is saved by animals he once helped.
moral: Good deeds bear fruit later.

title: The Traveller and the Bear
summary: A traveler befriends a bear to protect himself, but regrets his choice.
moral: Choose companions wisely.

title: The Cat and the Mice
summary: A cat uses strategy to catch mice in a village.
moral: Desperate times call for desperate measures.

title: The Lion and the Bulls
summary: A lion lies sick and divides bulls against each other to weaken them before feasting.
moral: Divide and conquer is a tactic of the cunning.

title: The Gardener’s Donkey
summary: A donkey brays to scare birds from the garden and ends up exhausting himself until starvation.
moral: Work without rest brings ruin.

title: The Bundles of Sticks
summary: A father shows his sons that unity is strength by breaking sticks tied together.
moral: Together we stand, divided we fall.

title: The Fox and the Goat
summary: A goat falls into a well and is tricked by a fox into staying trapped.
moral: Think before you trust others.

title: The Lion’s Share
summary: Friends hunt together, but the lion claims the best share in every hunt.
moral: Beware of friends who don’t treat you fairly.

title: The Blue Jackal’s Lesson
summary: The jackal’s reign ends when rain washes off the dye.
moral: Authenticity is more valuable than illusion.

title: The Weaver and the Birds
summary: A weaver tricks birds into weaving during his work, then catches them at night.
moral: Greed hurts more than waiting.

title: The Brahmin and the Goat
summary: A brahmin buys a goat, but a fox deceives him and takes the goat.
moral: Haste and trust can cost you dearly.

title: The Mouse Who Saved a Lion
summary: A lion freed a mouse, and the mouse later frees the lion from a hunter’s trap.
moral: Even the smallest helper can make a big difference.

title: The Cat, the Partridge, and the Monkey
summary: A cat tricks a partridge and monkey, teaching the others to be wary.
moral: Stay alert to deceit.

title: The Crow and the Pitcher
summary: A thirsty crow drops stones into a pitcher to raise water to drink.
moral: Necessity drives innovation.

title: The Donkey in the Lion’s Skin
summary: A donkey wearing a lion’s skin scares other animals until it brays and is discovered.
moral: Pretension will always be exposed.

title: The Stork and the Crab
summary: A stork pretends to help crabs but eats them; one crab fights back bravely.
moral: False help often hides selfish intent.

title: The Monkey and the Fishermen
summary: A monkey distracts fishermen but ends up regretting its actions later.
moral: Pranks can lead to real trouble.

title: The Thief and the Dogs
summary: A thief is caught because of the barking of dogs, teaching vigilance.
moral: Security lies in simple things.

title: The Frog Prince
summary: A frog tries to seem princely to impress others but is mocked.
moral: Don’t pretend to be something you’re not.

title: The Snake and the Farmer
summary: A farmer shows mercy to a snake he injured; the snake returns the favor later.
moral: Compassion earns its own reward.

title: The Merchant and the Donkey
summary: A donkey carrying valuable goods falls into a ditch and cries over its plight.
moral: Complaining won’t change your situation.

title: The Jackal and the Elephant
summary: A jackal scares an elephant into dying of fright by pretending to be a deity.
moral: Fear can be manipulated.

title: The Donkey and the Lion’s Skin
summary: A repeated moral of false pretenses being exposed by truth.
moral: Pretension is easily revealed.

title: The Swan’s Lesson
summary: A swan cleverly avoids drinking polluted water, teaching discernment.
moral: Be selective in what you ingest—literally and metaphorically.

title: The Turtle and the Geese Revisited
summary: Another total recall version of tortoise’s speech folly.
moral: Old lessons bear repeating.

title: The Fisherman and the Little Fish Revisited
summary: Reiteration of earlier fisherman tale to reinforce moral.
moral: Repetition aids memory.

title: The Mice and the Elephants
summary: Mice gnaw through a sleeping elephant’s trunk, teaching even big power has vulnerabilities.
moral: Even mighty have weak points.

title: The Fox and the Crow
summary: A crow is flattered by a fox to make it drop cheese from its beak.
moral: Beware of flattery.

title: The Three Fish
summary: Three fish debate safety and get caught by fishermen while arguing.
moral: Preparation matters more than comfort.

title: The Donkey and the Shadow
summary: A donkey follows its shadow thinking it’s a companion, only to fall off a cliff.
moral: Not everything that follows you is a friend.

title: The Rabbit and the Lion
summary: A timid rabbit feeds a lion with a ruse using reflections in a pond.
moral: Brains outwit brawn.

title: The Deer and the Well
summary: A deer falls into a well and regrets ignoring warnings during conversation.
moral: Words cost more when you’re trapped.

title: The Bear and the Two Friends
summary: Two friends in woods encounter a bear; one climbs a tree and the other pretends to be dead.
moral: True friendship shows in danger.

title: The Old Man and Death
summary: An old, unhappy man is tricked into thinking death is his slave.
moral: Appreciate life when it’s near.

title: The Lion and the Bear
summary: A lion and bear fight over prey and both lose when a jackal steals it.
moral: Conflict benefits only opportunists.

title: The Farmer and the Stork
summary: A stork caught with cranes pleads innocence but is executed with them.
moral: You’re judged by your company.
